title: The Northern Healing and Recovery Program (NHARP)

sections.heading: About NHARP
sections.text: The Northern Healing and Recovery Program (NHARP) at Kids First Australia aims to provide therapeutic support to victim-survivors of family violence including infants, children, young people and their parents and/or primary caregiver. NHARP facilitates individual and group sessions with children and young people and their caregivers to promote safety and healing.

sections.heading: Who can access the service?
sections.text:
The program is free and available to people who live in Banyule, Darebin, Hume, Moreland, Nillumbik, Whittlesea, or Yarra local government areas and have experienced family violence, including:

• children aged 0-14 years and their caregiver
• young people over 15 years with or without their caregiver
• adult victim-survivors with children

sections.heading: How we can help
sections.text:
NHARP supports families to recover after living in a household where there has been family violence. We specialise in trauma-informed care that focuses on helping children and their caregivers to feel safe and to strengthen their relationships.

We help adults to understand their own and their child's experience of the violence and learn ways to support their family's wellbeing and recovery.

sections.heading: NHARP Groups
sections.text: NHARP offers groups for women and children who have experienced family violence.

sections.heading: Mothers in Mind
sections.text: A safe and supportive program for mothers and their children aged 0 - 5 years old to build confidence and connection after hurtful experiences.

sections.heading: Connections
sections.text: A group for mothers to connect in a safe and welcoming space.

sections.heading: Referrals
sections.text: For all referrals, please send through to the Berry Street intake team

sections.heading: Interested?
sections.text:
For more information about the The Northern Healing and Recovery Program (NHARP), please fill in the below form and one of lovely Intake and Engagement team members will be in touch with you shortly. Alternatively if you would like to speak to someone on the phone please call (03) 9450 0900.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

header: A family violence therapeutic program that partners with victim/survivors, children and their families

title: Access to Early Learning

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text:
Access to Early Learning (AEL) aims to increase participation in three-year-old kindergarten for children experiencing vulnerability from families with complex needs. It provides an outreach service, with a dedicated facilitator visiting participating families weekly. Over the course of a year, the facilitator will build relationships with parents that promote stronger engagement with learning, both in the home and at kindergarten. The AEL facilitator will also create important connections and collaboration between the family, the early childhood education and care service and its educator and other services in support of the child’s learning and development.

AEL facilitators will support at least 16 children and their families for one year. The program is being established now in order to identify, engage and enrol eligible children so that they can commence a free or low-cost kindergarten program for 15 hours per week in Term 1, 2022.

Kids First is a proud Access to Early Learning partner and will be facilitating the AEL program for Whittlesea and Mitchell Shire.

sections.heading: Early, sustained participation in a high-quality kindergarten program benefits all children, but children experiencing vulnerability have most to gain. A substantial body of research shows improved social, learning and development outcomes for these child
How AEL works
sections.text:
Kids First’s AEL facilitator will take a strengths-based approach to working with families and services. Our facilitator will:

• Work with parents to support and focus on children’s learning and development needs
• Strengthen parent capacity to support in home learning and provide tailored support to each child dependent on their needs
• Address family barriers to kindergarten access, as well as any practical barriers to participating in kindergarten
• Strengthen the links between kindergarten and in-home learning
• Collaborate with educators and ECEC services to support family engagement.

sections.heading: Eligibility criteria
sections.text:
Kids First can accept referrals to the AEL program by either Child Protection, The Orange Door, Child FIRST/family services or Enhanced Maternal and Child Health (EMCH) services.

For a child to be referred, their family must have two or more of the following characteristics:

• be known to Child Protection
• include a parent with an intellectual or physical disability
• have a history of family violence
• have a history of mental health issues
• have a history of sexual assault
• have a history of alcohol and/or drug abuse
•the child referred to AEL has an intellectual or physical disability.

In addition:

• children must be aged three by 30 April to participate in a program for the calendar year (In-home learning and family engagement may start prior to the child commencing kindergarten).
• This is a voluntary program; however families must be willing to participate in planning and in-home learning activities to participate.

Other factors, such as homelessness, young parenthood, social isolation, and refugee status, are considered in addition to determine priority of access.

sections.heading: Referrals
sections.text:
Kids First can accept referrals to the AEL program by either Child Protection, The Orange Door, Child FIRST/family services or Enhanced Maternal and Child Health (EMCH) services.

Kids First will review referrals and establish a process for prioritising access into the program.

The 2022 intake of AEL in Whittlesea/Mitchell will begin in September, with a view to engaging families and establishing relationships so that children can commence three-year-old kindergarten in Term 1, 2022. This means that a child must be three years old by 30 April 2022 in order to be eligible for the program.

Leave your details below and one of our lovely Intake and Engagement team members will be in touch in regard to your referral for Access to Early Learning

title: The KODY Project

sections.heading: About KODY
sections.text: The KODY project recognises the combined impact of harmful behaviours, drugs and alcohol, on family relationships. During the KODY program, fathers will be participating in both the Caring Dads program and AOD counselling, while mothers, fathers and their children will have the opportunity to work with Kids in Focus.

sections.heading: KODY - Caring Dads program
sections.text: A program to help fathers who have used violence, to improve and repair their relationships with their children. Caring Dads supports child-centred parenting practices and a reduction in controlling, abusive and neglectful parenting to enhance the safety and wellbeing of children. It seeks to develop father’s ability to engage in respectful, non-abusive parenting with the mothers of their children. Fathers will participate in AOD counselling alongside the Caring Dads program as part of the KODY project.

sections.heading: KODY - Kids in Focus program

link.text: Learn more about Kids in Focus

sections.text: Kids in Focus is a specialist child and family support program that provides a range of intensive services to families affected by parental alcohol and other drug problems. The program aims to identify and address both the needs of the parents and their children.

sections.heading: Interested in finding out more?
sections.text:
For more information about The KODY Project please complete the below form and one of our lovely Intake and Engagement team members will be in touch with you. Alternatively if you would like to speak to someone on the phone please call us on
(03) 9450 0900.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

title: Sing & Grow

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text:
Families can expect to have fun making music together and learn new ways to support child development.

We use percussion instruments, drums, ribbons, balls and parachutes. Every family receives some take home resources and access to our online family hub to help them to make music at home.

sections.heading: How does Sing & Grow work?
sections.text:
A total of 10 families with children from birth to 5 years can join this program.

Groups usually meet for an hour once a week, for 6-8 weeks.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: This program is fully funded by a Westpac Impact Grant.

title: Mentoring Mums

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text: The program is for mothers and caregivers who have children up to and including primary school age (0 - 11 years of age), who are currently using a service at Kids First.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text: Mentors are there to team up with mums to achieve their parenting goals. This is done through spending regular time with mums and their children, checking in and listening when mums are experiencing challenges and assisting mums to go to social activities and appointments.

sections.heading: How does it work?
sections.text:
1. Kids First can refer eligible and interested mothers into the program and will arrange a home visit with the mentor

2. At this first visit the mother, mentor and key worker will agree on a plan that includes their goals together and regular times to visit (usually 2-4 hours per week during business hours).

3. The mum and mentor regularly review their plan, to see how the goals are progressing.

4. The mentoring will finish up when the goals are met and the mother doesn't feel like she needs the support any longer, or up to 12 weeks after the mother finishes working with Kids First.

sections.heading: Who are the mentors?
sections.text:
Mentors are women who may also be mums, and have experience with babies, children and parenting.

Many mentors have worked in areas like child care, social work, teaching, and other roles that provide child and family support.

Mentors are part of the Kids First Volunteer Teams, who all complete training and have current Police and Working with Children Checks.

sections.heading: Interested?
sections.text:
For more information about Mentoring Mums please fill in the form below and one of lovely Intake and Engagement team members will be in touch with you shortly. Alternatively if you would like to speak to someone on the phone please call us on (03) 9450 0900.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

title: The Orange Door

sections.heading: What is The Orange Door?
sections.text:
The Orange Door is a free service for adults, children and young people who are experiencing or have experienced family violence and families who need extra support with the care of children.

Workers at The Orange Door also know that people continue to be affected by family violence long after the violence stops. If you have experienced family violence in the past and would like help now, contact The Orange Door.

The Orange Door is run in partnership by Kids First Australia, Family Safety Victoria and Victoria State Government.

title: Sensory Room

sections.heading: What is a Sensory Room?
sections.text: A Sensory Room is a room purposefully designed as a safe space. It features special lighting, music, objects and furniture. It encourages tuning into the senses to understand what works for individuals in terms of regulating emotions, communicating or renewing focus.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text:
Our practitioners regularly use the Sensory Room with our clients to further enhance the 'attachment' or the relationship between parents and children, improving communication, regulating reactions to emotions and strengthening connection within families.

Our Sensory Room features include an egg chair, coloured lighting, a bubble tube with remote for changing colours, weighted objects, body sox and stepping stones, among other things that can be explored by parents/caregivers and children together.

sections.heading: How can a Sensory Room benefit families?
sections.text:
All people first learn about the world and their relationships through their senses. Playing and interacting with people and their environment stimulates the senses and creates engagement with others. People receive information from the environment through the senses and process it through the brain which then allows the body to respond.

Those who have been in very stressful situations, or have had experiences of childhood trauma, may have emotional and body effects, some of which may be related to sensory needs. For example, some children experiencing childhood neglect may have missed out on sufficient touch, which effects their attachment style and could result in touch sensitivity.

Additionally, parents and children who have experienced family violence may have heightened stress levels or hypervigilance as their nervous system is in overdrive in an attempt to be alert to danger and create safety. This can affect how their body and brain may take in sensory information, process and modulate sensory information and affect their ability to regulate emotions and to carry out coordinated movements.

In both these examples, the relationship between parent and child can be strengthened by understanding that we each have our own unique sensory preferences, and we can build sensory connections with a view to calming, grounding and relaxing together and experiencing playful times and enjoyable moments.

sections.subtitle: Kids First
sections.text_plain:
Prior to using sensory methods I had never seen this young person smile or laugh. He lacked hope and often spoke of feeling he couldn’t be helped,
yet he began to respond to the Sensory room, particularly the egg chair, and used that to swivel back or forth to indicate his feelings...
sections.title: Clinical practitioner

sections.text:

title: Dads Circle of Security

sections.heading: What is Dads Circle of Security?
sections.text:
Dads Circle of Security is a parenting program, designed to helps dads to understand their child’s behaviour and to build and strengthen a secure relationship with their child. 

Decades of research have confirmed that secure children exhibit increased empathy, greater self-esteem, better relationships with parents and peers, enhanced school readiness, and an increased capacity to handle emotions more effectively when compared with children who are not secure.

sections.heading: Benefits of Dads Circle of Security
sections.text:
Over the course of the program we cover:

• Ways to enhance the development of your child's self-esteem, trust and sense of security.
• Supporting the creation of a secure base from which your child feels able to explore their world, knowing there is a safe haven to return to.
• Strategies to build confidence as a parent so that you can enjoy parenting and take on new challenges along the way.

sections.heading: How does Dads Circle of Security work?
sections.text: Dads Circle of Security is a free group program run by Kids First. Fathers of children aged 0-5 years, residing in the north east of Melbourne are very welcome to participate.

sections.heading: Interested?
sections.text:

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

title: Positive Parenting Program

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text: Positive Parenting Program (Triple P) is an evidence based program that supports parents to raise happy babies and confident kids by giving them tools and tips to use with confidence.

sections.heading: Overview

You can attend one or all Triple P sessions where we will share ideas, tools and tips to guide your child's behaviour.

Triple P's simple, practical strategies have been proven to work around the world, helping parents raise happy, confident children; set family routines and rules that everyone can follow; and balance work and family life with less stress.

title: Recovery & Education For Sexual Exploitation & Trauma (Reset)

sections.heading: What is RESET?
sections.text: RESET is a free group service providing therapeutic psychoeducation to support parents and carers of children and young people at risk of sexual exploitation.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text:
Our skilled and professional team work with families to:

• Explore and process yours and your child’s experiences of sexual exploitation.
• Learn, develop and utilise tools to increase safety and effective communication with children and young people.
• Develop your understanding of sexual exploitation with tailored information and resources.
• Work through ways to support healing so that your child and family can RESET.

title: B2A - Crossroads

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text: B2A Crossroads looks to support boys developing into teenagers by providing education about commonly faced issues and challenges as they mature.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text:
The program aims to help young boys increase their understanding of self and others, through building their emotional understanding, managing challenging feelings, developing greater levels of respect in their relationships and improving their self-esteem.

The theme of ‘Crossroads’ is explored in every session. Young people are supported by facilitators to consider the ways in which, throughout their daily lives, they are faced with choices. It’s at these moments, these crossroads, that they can make decisions about who they want to be and how they want to respond to build positive, respectful relationships and good mental health.

sections.heading: B2A Themes
sections.text:
Identity: (present and future).

Feelings: exploring understanding of different feelings and body mapping.

Building emotional capacity: exploring the understanding of different feelings, speaking and unpacking the hard emotions that young people, particularly boys might not often address.

Consent: The CARE factor, breaking down the areas around consent, age of consent, respect and equality in these matters.

Relationships: exploring relationships for young people, what makes a healthy relationship, and how to make responsible, respectful choices during, and when they end.

Gender roles: critically unpacking masculinity and femininity, differences between sex and gender, macro, meso and micro systems and the impact of traditional gender roles.

Cyber Safety: the legal and ethical issues related to sexting, online bullying and pornography.

sections.heading: How does B2A work?
sections.text: Boys 2 Adolescents is a free 8-session early intervention program delivered in schools to support boys aged 11–13 years.

sections.heading: Interested?
sections.text:
Boys 2 Adolescents is a group program run in schools. We welcome enquiries from schools in Melbourne's north east to express interest in this program. For more information please fill in the form below and one of our lovely Intake and Engagement team members will be in touch with you. title: Family Services

sections.heading: Our Family Services Team
sections.text: Through our support programs, we partner with families to strengthen their relationships and work through challenging times.

sections.heading: Our services
sections.text:
Working closely with children, adolescents and adults who are experiencing or have experienced challenging life circumstances.

Individual, therapeutic and group-based support.

Providing linkages into other services such as disability and mental health services, family violence support, adult health services, child health services and advocacy which may include housing, Centrelink and the Department of Education and Training.

sections.heading: How does Family Services work?
sections.text:
A case worker is allocated to you and your family and will meet with you regularly.

Together you’ll work through the needs of your family and develop clear goals which are regularly reviewed so that things stay on track.

Appointments can be in your own home or at Kids First’s Heidelberg or Thomastown centres, or another agreed venue.

We will coordinate a care team response with any other services you are using.

Our team also runs a variety of groups throughout the year for children and parents/caregivers.

sections.heading: Interested in finding out more?
sections.text:
The Orange Door takes all Integrated Family Services enquiries for this region. Please contact The Orange Door and let them know if Kids First is your preferred Family Service.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

title: Family Therapy

sections.heading: What is Family Therapy?
sections.text: Family Therapy is an opportunity to discuss thoughts and feelings as well as understand each others’ experiences, build on strengths and identify ways to make positive changes.

sections.heading: What defines a Family?
sections.text: There is no one definition of family and at Kids First we welcome them all.

sections.heading: Who can come to Family Therapy?
sections.text: The whole family! Whether it be individually or as a group, everybody is welcome. Your therapist may want to see all members of your family together or work with family members separately. What Family Therapy looks like is different for every family.

sections.heading: How will you know if Family Therapy is right for you?
sections.text:
We will discuss how family therapy can support you and your family. A session can be arranged between you and a family therapist to better understand if Family Therapy is right for you.

If you decide that Family Therapy is the right fit for you we will have a discussion about who should attend. The first appointment will be a Family Consultation, when everyone can talk about their strengths and worries in the family, and plan what their next steps will be.

sections.heading: Who can access Family Therapy?
sections.text: Family Services at Kids First offers Family Therapy at both Thomastown and Heidelberg centres, at no cost.

sections.heading: Interested?
sections.text: To access Family Therapy you will need to already be a client of Kids First. The referral pathway into Kids First's Family Services is through The Orange Door. For more information about Family Services and Family Therapy please fill in the form below and one of our lovely Orange Door team members will be in touch with you shortly. Alternatively if you would like to speak to someone on the phone please contact The Orange Door on 1800 319 355.

header: We believe that all families have their own strengths. Families come up against changes and challenges in life that can be stressful. This is where our Family Therapy service can help.
seo_description: Family Therapy is an opportunity to discuss thoughts and feelings, understand each others’ experiences, build on strengths and make positive changes.
seo_keywords: Family therapy, family support, family therapist, helping families through therapy, family support services

title: Moving On

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text:
If you have experienced family violence, it can impact on your life in loads of different ways. You might find your experiences have affected your confidence, self-esteem, study, relationships with family and friends and trust in other people.

Moving On is a comprehensive program that aims to to support the development of the future of young people who have been affected by family violence.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text: Moving On focuses on building the things that you want to feel better about by providing, individual, family and group therapy using evidenced informed approaches.

sections.heading: How does Moving On work?
sections.text: Moving On is a free 8-week group program for young people. Moving On is run by Kids First as part of the Northern Healing and Recovery Program (NHARP).

sections.heading: Interested?

For more information about Moving On please fill in the below form and one of our lovely Intake and Engagement team members will be in touch with you. Alternatively if you would like to speak to someone on the phone please call us on (03) 9450 0900.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

title: Promoting First Relationships - program

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text:
Promoting First Relationships ( PFR) is a home visiting program that can really build your sense of confidence as a parent and a positive connection between you and your child.

After strong evidence of its success in the United States, Kids First sourced the PFR program and is the only organisation trained in Australia to use the PFR techniques. This means our clients who are parents or caregivers, can tap into this amazing program and Kids First's free resources.

PFR is flexible and adaptable and is delivered in your home. Our practitioner will work with you depending what your needs and priorities are, to enhance your relationship with your child. This may be one week, or up to 10. In addition to visiting your home, our practitioner will provide you with handouts and video content so that what you learn as a family is embedded and will last for the long term.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text: Participating in PFR will help you to understand your child's behaviours by looking at the feelings that sit behind them, recognise how to support your child's social and emotional health and acknowledge your own needs. It is designed to increase your confidence as a caregiver and strengthen the attachment between you and your child.

sections.heading: How does Promoting First Relationships work?
sections.text:
Promoting First Relationships is a free program and is run by Kids First as part of the Northern Healing and Recovery Program.

Common things PFR can help parents/caregivers with:

• Building a positive attachment relationship with your child.
• Understanding your child’s difficult behaviors, and looking at the feelings and needs behind these behaviors.
• Understanding how to support your child’s social and emotional health.
• Discussing strategies for coping with difficult times as a parent.
• Understanding ways you can help your child through emotionally difficult experiences.
• Understanding your own social and emotional needs.

sections.subtitle: Parent participant
sections.text_plain: "It (PFR) has been a fantastic support especially in my confidence as a parent. Before the program I doubted myself a lot thinking I must be doing something wrong or could be doing something better. You helped me see all the little things I was doing well and reflect on what I also needed. You always made me feel comfortable to share and I felt you very quickly picked up on our needs and went out of your way to accommodate these. You explained everything so well and were inclusive in how we worked together. I never felt judged and the way you delivered feedback was encouraging and motivating. A huge thank you, you have made a huge difference in my life and hopefully a flow on effect to my child’s life.”

title: Connections

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text:
Family violence can have a major impact on the well-being of women and their children. It can shatter self-esteem and confidence, affect parenting and strain family relationships.

Connections is a group program to support families to heal from the impacts of family violence. Run over 8 sessions, the group is open to mothers of children of all ages to connect in a safe & welcoming space.

Connections is run by Northern Healing and Recovery Program (N-HARP), a family violence therapeutic program that partners with victim/survivors, children, and their families.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text:
Together we will explore:

• How experiences of family violence can impact on your relationships with your children
• How to build confidence in your parenting and strengthen connections between you and your child
• Strategies for managing this challenging time we are all facing.

sections.heading: How does Connections work?
sections.text: The group is open to mothers of children of all ages, to connect in a safe and welcoming space. The group is run across eight weeks. This is a free program run by Kids First as part of the Northern Healing and Recovery Program.

sections.heading: NHARP
sections.text:
The Northern Healing and Recovery Program (NHARP) is a family violence therapeutic program that partners with adult victim/survivors, children and families. NHARP is delivered by Kids First Australia, Berry Street, inTouch, Thorne Harbour Health, Rubix Support and VACCA.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

title: Infant Family Services

sections.heading: Infant Family Services Team
sections.text: Our team is passionate about working alongside parents and their young children. Team members are trained to share parenting information and approaches that are supported by evidence from research studies. You can be assured that we are skilled and experienced to provide effective support to you, your child and your family.

sections.heading: Our services
sections.text:
We take a client-led approach, so what we do depends on your needs and goals. We provide support in your home and we tailor our work around your priorities.

The support can be short-term or longer-term, depending on what works for you. For example, you may want more confidence to manage tricky or more challenging times with your child, or to know what your baby is telling you, or to feel closer to your child. Where you want to begin is where we will start.

Depending on your needs, we offer an evidenced based 10-session program called ‘Promoting First Relationships’, that supports the relationship between you and your child, and supports you to build your confidence in understanding yourself and your baby. We also have useful resources and information about parenting, and children’s emotional and behavioural development.

sections.heading: Who the team works with
sections.text:
Expecting parents and/or parents and carers who have a child aged 0-5.

Parents and carers who would like support to develop their relationship with their child and who would like support and resources for their child’s emotional and behavioural development

Families who live in Darebin, Yarra, Banyule, Nillumbik and Whittlesea.

We know that families have a range of structures and diverse backgrounds, and we accept and welcome referrals for diverse families.

sections.heading: Interested in finding out more?
sections.text:
The Orange Door takes all Integrated Family Services (IFS) enquiries for this region. Please contact The Orange Door and let them know if Kids First is your preferred Family Service.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

title: School Readiness - program

sections.heading: What is Kids First Trauma-Informed Consultancy and Coaching?
sections.text: Kids First School Readiness packages equip early years educators with the tools they need to support children’s social and emotional needs before they transition to school.

sections.heading: Accreditation

link.text: Victorian State Government School readiness funding menu.

sections.text: We are an accredited School Readiness Provider as part of the Victorian State Government School readiness funding menu.

sections.heading: Our unique service offering
sections.text: Adopting a trauma informed and relational approach, our School Readiness consultancy packages deliver a holistic perspective to child wellbeing derived from first-hand experience at our own early childhood centres.

sections.heading: What will I gain from Kids First Trauma-informed Consultancy and Coaching?
sections.text:
With Kids First, you will learn how to:

Support children experiencing vulnerability to reach their full potential while understanding and supporting the child's family.

Identify the underlying factors impacting educational outcomes.

Strengthen factors that promote resilience within the child and the child's family.

Assist in supporting the child to arrive at school ready to learn and thrive.

sections.heading: How to access our services
sections.text:
All of our services are available through the School Readiness Funding Menu. We will prioritise all bookings from services who have included us on their School Readiness Funding plans.

If you are not yet eligible for School Readiness Funding or you did not include us on your plan, please contact us and we can discuss availability to support your service. If you are in the process of developing your School Readiness Funding plan, please contact us and we can support you to develop a tailored package to ensure you make the most of your funding allocation.

title: Tuning into Teens

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text: Tuning into Teens (TinT) is an evidence based program that supports parents to feel more confident to connect with their teens, understand their needs and challenges, support them to manage strong emotions and reduce conflict.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text:
One of the things parents find most helpful about attending this series is the chance to share experiences that are common for parents at this time, and hear new ideas about connecting with teenagers.

Tuning into Teens shows you how to help your teen develop emotional intelligence - a key lifelong skill. Emotional intelligence is the capability of individuals to recognise their own emotions and those of others, tell the difference between different feelings and label them appropriately, use emotional information to guide thinking and behavior, and adjust emotions to adapt to environments.

sections.heading: How does TinT work?
sections.text: Tuning into Teens is a free program run by Kids First for parents who live in Yarra, Darebin, Whittlesea, Banyule and Nillumbik areas.

sections.heading: Interested?

For more information about Tuning into Teens please fill in the form below and one of lovely Intake and Engagement team members will be in touch with you shortly. Alternatively if you would like to speak to someone on the phone please call us on (03) 9450 0900.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

title: Tuning into Kids

sections.heading: About this Program
sections.text: Tuning into Kids (TiK) provides parents and carers with skills in emotion coaching. Emotion coaching is about recognising, understanding and managing your own emotions as a caregiver as well as your children’s emotions. When children develop these emotional skills they are better equipped to negotiate the ups and downs of life.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text: TiK is an evidence-based program. Extensive research has shown that it makes a difference to parents and children.

sections.heading: How does Tuning into Kids work?
sections.text: TiK is a free program run by Kids First. It is available to parents who live in Yarra, Darebin, Whittlesea, Banyule and Nillumbik areas.

title: Stand Up!

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text:
When it comes to young relationships, the rules of engagement have changed. The digital age brings a new set of challenges for young people. Social media, selfies and sexting are pressures to navigate and the threat of being sexually exploited is very real.

Stand Up! was developed and piloted by Kids First’s Sexual Abuse Counselling and Prevention Program (SACAPP) team. Delivered in schools to Year 8 students, Stand Up! runs across four sessions.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text:
The program uniquely bridges the gap between existing school curriculum around cyber safety and sex education, and explores sexual relationships while promoting safety, space and boundaries – offline and online. The program content, delivered through scenarios to explore individually and in small groups, supports young people to consider the complexities of negotiating authentic and healthy intimate relationships.

Students are led through discussions about how to critically think about healthy sexual and intimate relationships in their own lives and how to safeguard self and others from being sexually exploited.

sections.heading: How does Stand Up! work?
sections.text:
Stand Up! is a prevention program that runs across 3-4 sessions and is delivered in high schools by the Kids First.

Schools interested in participating in the program, are encouraged to contact Kids First.

Westpac's 'Safer Children, Safer Communities' program has funded Kids First to broaden the reach of the Stand Up! program through producing digital resources so that the Stand Up! material can be delivered to more young people in more schools.

sections.heading: Key learning outcomes
sections.text:
At completion of the program, young people will be able to:

• Define sexual exploitation
• Identify risk scenarios in healthy and unhealthy relationships
• Understand the role of consent and the law in sexual relationships
• Define, understand and respond to grooming
• Develop real life strategies to deal with risk of sexual exploitation, grooming, and managing unhealthy relationships
• Identify barriers of seeking support and advice and how to overcome these.

sections.subtitle: Kids First Clinical Practitioner
sections.text_plain: Through our work we have been able to have real conversations with young people about their day to day interactions around intimate relationships and navigation of consent, hook up culture and how grooming/sexual exploitation looks in the 21st century.”
sections.title: Thomas

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

sections.heading: Overview

title: Caring Dads - program

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text:
In Australia, there are few services helping men who have used violence that specifically focus on improving parenting practices.

Caring Dads is Australia’s first evidence-based behavior-change program helping fathers who have used violence, to improve their relationship with their children.

Caring Dads supports better parenting practices and a reduction in violence to enhance the safety and wellbeing of children. It seeks to develop fathers’ ability to engage in respectful, non-abusive parenting with the mothers of their children. The program recognises the importance of making fathers equally accountable for their behaviour and for their children’s wellbeing — a role that is often assigned to women as protectors of their children.

sections.heading: Program goals
sections.text:
• To develop sufficient trust and motivation to engage men in the process of examining their fathering
• To increase fathers’ awareness and application of child-centred fathering
• To increase fathers’ awareness of, and responsibility for, abusive and neglectful fathering and the impact of this on their children
• To rebuild trust with children and plan for the future.

sections.heading: Is this program for you?
sections.text:
Do you live in north east Melbourne, Western Melbourne or inner Gippsland?

Do you have regular contact with your child/children?

Are you worried about how your behaviour is impacting your relationship with your children?

Are you willing and able to attend a 17 week program?

Do you want to be the best dad you can be?

If you have answered yes to these questions then Caring Dads may be a good fit for you.

sections.heading: How does Caring Dads work?
sections.text:
The Caring Dads program is made up of:

• a 17-session, group-parenting intervention for fathers. Sessions happen once weekly
• systematic outreach to mothers to ensure their safety and freedom from coercion
• ongoing, collaborative case management of fathers with existing service providers and other professionals involved with fathers’ families.

sections.subtitle: Caring Dads client
sections.text_plain:
I just wanted to thank you for your care and professionalism while I worked through some pretty important issues. Changes have been made and maintained, especially in my relationship with my son. I'm more consistent, and honest, and respectful. Generally speaking, I'm more mature and compassionate, having let go of the baggage of the past.

Thanks again, and good luck with the next blokes who come knocking on your door.
sections.title: Father

title: Sexual Abuse Counselling and Prevention Program

sections.heading: About this program
sections.text: Every child or young person is unique. The type of therapy our team use with clients is therefore tailored to what will work best for them, and is based on that particular child or young person’s interests, learning style and developmental stage. Some of the techniques we use include: talking, puppets, individual work, group work, art, music, drama, sand tray and writing.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.text:
The Therapeutic team takes a whole-of-family approach. Participation of family members and carers in therapeutic work is vital to support the child or young person. We also acknowledge the significant impact that sexual abuse and or problematic and harmful sexualised behaviours can have on families and carers ensuring that they too receive support. 

We do this by helping families and carers understand what has happened, what the impacts are and how they can best comfort their child to help them heal.

sections.heading: Benefits of counselling
sections.text:
Kids First understands that sexual abuse and problematic or harmful sexualised behaviours impacts on children, young people and their families/carers. Our service will therefore support your child to process their experience in a safe and supportive way.

We recognise the benefit of a therapeutic support and consider the age and stage of development of the child and young person and work toward building resilience and safety for their future.

sections.heading: Who we assist
sections.text:
Children and young people up to the age of 18 years old who have been sexually abused and their family members who reside in the City of Banyule, Darebin, Yarra or Whittlesea, or in the Shire of Nillumbik.

Children aged 3 - 10 who have displayed problematic sexualised behaviours and who reside in the City of Banyule, Darebin, Yarra, Whittlesea and the Shire of Nillumbik.

Children and young people up to the age of 18 years who have engaged in problematic and or harmful sexualised behaviours and who reside in the City of Banyule, Darebin, Yarra or Whittlesea, or in the Shire of Nilumbik.

If this service is not available in your area, please contact us so we can help you get in touch with the right people.

article.header_text: Research to determine the CMiM program’s effectiveness in improving understanding of family violence and mother-child relationships.
sections:
Heading
About Children and Mothers in Mind (CMiM)
Text

Children and Mothers in Mind (CMiM) was an Australian-first program designed for mothers and children under four years, who have experienced trauma such as family violence, childhood abuse or sexual assault.

Through a mother and child play-based group program, it focused on the needs of mothers who have found that the hurt they have experienced has made parenting difficult, and resources them with strategies to become the mothers they want to be.

CMiM resourced mothers to:
• Talk about parenting issues and learn from other mothers who have had similar experiences through the group dynamic
• Build a positive mother-child relationship through spending quality time playing with their child
• Discover helpful ways to cope with their anger, worry and stress in a safe and supportive environment
• Increase their confidence in responding to their children in a sensitive and caring manner and learn how to support children exposed to trauma
• Explore and learn what helps children feel safe and secure
• Bond with other participants to reduce mother-child isolation
• Find practical ways to take some time out for themselves during this busy stage of life.

Heading
Findings of evaluation project
Text

The University of Melbourne has evaluated CMiM with a number of aims including understanding the extent to which participating in the program changes mothers’ understanding about the impact of domestic and family violence on parenting and how effectively it improves mother-child relationships.

Heading
Snapshot of findings
Title
Should be Empty if this page is an article type
Subtitle
- Participant
Text
Doing these exercises and talking about things has made me realize that this connection is special and that it is unique. I am important to him and that was something that I felt my ex-partner had pretty much diminished in me.
Heading
Program origins
Text

CMiM incorporates:

• the Connections psycho-educational program for mothers and children experiencing violence in relationships, developed by Mothercraft in Canada

• the Mothers in Mind (MIM) playgroup-based program, developed by Dr Angelique Jenney (University of Calgary, Canada) Child Development Institute
• one-to-one support, through counselling, case support and referral, and brokerage.

The Child Development Institute (CDI), an accredited children’s mental health agency in Canada offering early intervention, family violence and early learning programs, initially developed the program in 2006. The CDI partnered with Kids First to deliver this program in Victoria.
article.seo_description: Research to determine the Children and Mothers in Mind program’s effectiveness in improving understanding of family violence and mother-child relationships.
article.seo_keywords: Children and Mothers in Mind, Children and Mothers in Mind program evaluation, supporting mothers, supporting children, effective parenting programs, effective parenting support
article.title: Children and Mothers in Mind

sections.heading: Further Reading
sections.text: Mothers in Mind is an evidence-based program designed specifically to meet the parenting needs of mothers (of children aged 4 and under) who have experienced family violence, childhood abuse or sexual assault.
